answer_llm: When using `flow_from_directory` in binary class mode, numeric class labels are assigned based on the alphabetical order of the folder names containing the images. The first folder alphabetically will receive the class label 0, while the second folder will receive the class label 1. For example, if the folders are named "dino" and "dragon", "dino" will be assigned the class label 0 and "dragon" will be assigned the class label 1.
answer_orig:
The command to read folders in the dataset in the tensorflow source code is:
for subdir in sorted(os.listdir(directory)):
…
Reference: https://github.com/keras-team/keras/blob/master/keras/preprocessing/image.py, line 563
This means folders will be read in alphabetical order. For example, in the case of a folder named dino, and another named dragon, dino will read first and will have class label 0, whereas dragon will be read in next and will have class label 1.
When a Keras model predicts binary labels, it will only return one value, and this is the probability of class 1 in case of sigmoid activation function in the last dense layer with 2 neurons. The probability of class 0 can be found out by:
prob(class(0)) = 1- prob(class(1))
In case of using from_logits to get results, you will get two values for each of the labels.
A prediction of 0.8 is saying the probability that the image has class label 1 (in this case dragon), is 0.8, and conversely we can infer the probability that the image has class label 0 is 0.2.
(Added by Memoona Tahira)
question: How are numeric class labels assigned to folders when using flow_from_directory with binary class mode?

answer_llm: Folders are read in alphabetical order when determining numeric class labels in `flow_from_directory` in TensorFlow. For instance, if there are folders named "dino" and "dragon", "dino" will be read first and assigned a class label of 0, while "dragon" will be read next and assigned a class label of 1.

When a Keras model predicts binary labels, it will only return one value, and this is the probability of class 1 in case of sigmoid activation function in the last dense layer with 2 neurons. The probability of class 0 can be found out by:
prob(class(0)) = 1- prob(class(1))
In case of using from_logits to get results, you will get two values for each of the labels.
A prediction of 0.8 is saying the probability that the image has class label 1 (in this case dragon), is 0.8, and conversely we can infer the probability that the image has class label 0 is 0.2.
(Added by Memoona Tahira)
question: In which order are folders read when determining numeric class labels in flow_from_directory in TensorFlow?

answer_llm: When predicting binary labels with a Keras model that uses a sigmoid activation function, the model returns a single value that represents the probability of class 1. For instance, a prediction of 0.8 indicates an 80% probability that the instance belongs to class 1. The probability of class 0 can be calculated as 1 minus the probability of class 1.
answer_orig:
The command to read folders in the dataset in the tensorflow source code is:
for subdir in sorted(os.listdir(directory)):
…
Reference: https://github.com/keras-team/keras/blob/master/keras/preprocessing/image.py, line 563
This means folders will be read in alphabetical order. For example, in the case of a folder named dino, and another named dragon, dino will read first and will have class label 0, whereas dragon will be read in next and will have class label 1.
When a Keras model predicts binary labels, it will only return one value, and this is the probability of class 1 in case of sigmoid activation function in the last dense layer with 2 neurons. The probability of class 0 can be found out by:
prob(class(0)) = 1- prob(class(1))
In case of using from_logits to get results, you will get two values for each of the labels.
A prediction of 0.8 is saying the probability that the image has class label 1 (in this case dragon), is 0.8, and conversely we can infer the probability that the image has class label 0 is 0.2.
(Added by Memoona Tahira)
question: What value is returned by a Keras model when predicting binary labels with a sigmoid activation function?

answer_llm:
To calculate the probability of class 0 when a Keras model predicts the probability of class 1, you can use the formula:

\[ \text{prob(class(0))} = 1 - \text{prob(class(1))} \]

This means that if the model predicts a probability of \( p \) for class 1, the probability for class 0 would be \( 1 - p \). For example, if the model predicts a probability of 0.8 for class 1, the probability for class 0 would be 0.2.
answer_orig:

…
Reference: https://github.com/keras-team/keras/blob/master/keras/preprocessing/image.py, line 563
This means folders will be read in alphabetical order. For example, in the case of a folder named dino, and another named dragon, dino will read first and will have class label 0, whereas dragon will be read in next and will have class label 1.
When a Keras model predicts binary labels, it will only return one value, and this is the probability of class 1 in case of sigmoid activation function in the last dense layer with 2 neurons. The probability of class 0 can be found out by:
prob(class(0)) = 1- prob(class(1))
In case of using from_logits to get results, you will get two values for each of the labels.
A prediction of 0.8 is saying the probability that the image has class label 1 (in this case dragon), is 0.8, and conversely we can infer the probability that the image has class label 0 is 0.2.
(Added by Memoona Tahira)
question: How can you calculate the probability of class 0 when a Keras model predicts the probability of class 1?

answer_llm: When using `from_logits` to get results in a Keras model, the two values represent the raw logits for each class. This means that instead of returning probabilities, the model outputs a pair of values: one for each class in a binary classification scenario. These values can be converted into probabilities using the softmax function, which will convert those logits into probabilities that sum to 1.

question: What do the two values represent when using from_logits to get results in a Keras model?

answer_llm: The values predicted by a neural network can be considered as likelihoods for classes, especially in the context of binary classification. It’s common to interpret the output of a neural network, particularly when using a sigmoid activation function, as the probability of falling into a specific class. For instance, a prediction of 0.8 indicates an 80% probability that the input belongs to class 1. Therefore, while the actual predicted values do have significance, they are best understood as probabilities or likelihoods of being in a particular class.

answer_llm: The purpose of the 'workers' parameter in 'model.fit()' is to speed up the data loading and generation during the training process. By specifying a value for 'workers', you can utilize multi-threading to enhance performance. The default value is set to "1", and it is suggested to experiment with different values between 1 and the total CPU count on your system to determine which performs best.

answer_llm:
To achieve reproducibility for training runs with TensorFlow, you can follow these instructions:

1. Set a seed for random number generation:
   ```python
   seed = 1234
   tf.keras.utils.set_random_seed(seed)
   ```

2. Enable operation determinism to ensure consistent results across runs:
   ```python
   tf.config.experimental.enable_op_determinism()
   ```

You can find more detailed instructions here: [TensorFlow Op Determinism](https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r2.8/api_docs/python/tf/config/experimental/enable_op_determinism). This setup will work if you execute the script multiple times.

tf.config.experimental.enable_op_determinism()
This will work for a script, if this gets executed multiple times.
Added by Sylvia Schmitt
question: How can I achieve reproducibility for training runs with TensorFlow?

answer_llm:
To ensure your TensorFlow model runs are reproducible, you should follow these steps:

1. Set a seed point for randomness:
   ```python
   seed = 1234
   tf.keras.utils.set_random_seed(seed)
   ```
2. Enable operation determinism in TensorFlow:
   ```python
   tf.config.experimental.enable_op_determinism()
   ```

By following these steps, your script will produce consistent results when executed multiple times. For more details, you can refer to the TensorFlow documentation [here](https://www.tensorflow.org/versions/r2.8/api_docs/python/tf/config/experimental/enable_op_determinism).

question: What steps should I follow to ensure my TensorFlow model runs are reproducible?

answer_llm: The role of the seed value for reproducibility in TensorFlow is to ensure consistent behavior across multiple script executions. By setting a specific seed value (e.g., `seed = 1234`), and using the command `tf.keras.utils.set_random_seed(seed)`, you can achieve reproducible training runs. Additionally, enabling operation determinism with `tf.config.experimental.enable_op_determinism()` further enhances reproducibility. This approach guarantees that if the script is executed multiple times, it will produce the same results each time.

answer_llm: Your Keras model training fails with the error 'Failed to find data adapter that can handle input: <class 'keras.src.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator'>, <class 'NoneType'>' because you may have unintentionally passed the image generator instead of the dataset to the model. The fix is to use the training and validation dataset returned from the `flow_from_directory` method. For example, instead of passing `train_gen` to `model.fit()`, you should use `train_ds` which is the dataset created with `train_gen.flow_from_directory(...)`.
answer_orig:
While training a Keras model you get the error “Failed to find data adapter that can handle input: <class 'keras.src.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator'>, <class 'NoneType'>” you may have unintentionally passed the image generator instead of the dataset to the model
train_gen = ImageDataGenerator(rescale=1./255)
train_ds = train_gen.flow_from_directory(…)
history_after_augmentation = model.fit(
train_gen, # this should be train_ds!!!
epochs=10,
validation_data=test_gen # this should be test_ds!!!
)
The fix is simple and probably obvious once pointed out, use the training and validation dataset (train_ds and val_ds) returned from flow_from_directory
Added by Tzvi Friedman
question: Why does my Keras model training fail with the error 'Failed to find data adapter that can handle input: <class 'keras.src.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator'>, <class 'NoneType'>'?

answer_llm: To avoid the 'Failed to find data adapter' error, you should have passed the training dataset (`train_ds`) returned from the `flow_from_directory` method instead of the image generator (`train_gen`). Make sure to use the training and validation datasets (`train_ds` and `val_ds`) for training the model.

question: What should I have passed to the model instead of the image generator to avoid the 'Failed to find data adapter' error?

answer_llm:
To avoid the 'Failed to find data adapter' issue when training a Keras model, you should use the training and validation datasets returned from the `flow_from_directory` method. Specifically, replace `train_gen` with `train_ds` in the `model.fit` call, and ensure that you are also using the appropriate validation dataset (`val_ds`). Here's a correct example:

```python
history_after_augmentation = model.fit(
    train_ds,  # use train_ds here
    epochs=10,
    validation_data=test_ds  # use test_ds here
)
```

For example, you should replace:

```python
history_after_augmentation = model.fit(
    train_gen,  # this should be train_ds!!!

)
```

with:

```python
history_after_augmentation = model.fit(
    train_ds,  # correct this to use train_ds
    epochs=10,
    validation_data=val_ds  # correct this to use val_ds
)
```

answer_llm:
To execute 'nvidia-smi' in a loop without using 'watch', you can use the command:

```
nvidia-smi -l <N seconds>
```

For example, to run 'nvidia-smi' every 2 seconds, use:

```
nvidia-smi -l 2
```

This will continuously update the output every 2 seconds until you interrupt it with CTRL+C.
answer_orig:
The command ‘nvidia-smi’ has a built-in function which will run it in subsequently updating it every N seconds without the need of using the command ‘watch’.
nvidia-smi -l <N seconds>
The following command will run ‘nvidia-smi’ every 2 seconds until interrupted using CTRL+C.
nvidia-smi -l 2
Added by Sylvia Schmitt
question: How can I execute 'nvidia-smi' in a loop without 'watch'?

answer_llm: The built-in function in 'nvidia-smi' for running it repeatedly is specified by the command `nvidia-smi -l <N seconds>`, where `<N seconds>` is the interval in seconds. For example, the command `nvidia-smi -l 2` will run 'nvidia-smi' every 2 seconds until interrupted with CTRL+C.

answer_llm:
The parameter count for a Conv2d layer is determined by the formula: 

\[
(\text{kernel height} \times \text{kernel width} \times \text{number of channels} + 1) \times \text{number of filters}
\]

For example, in a Conv2d layer defined as `tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(32, (3,3), activation='relu', input_shape=(150, 150, 3))`, the calculation for parameters is:

\[
(3 \times 3 \times 3 + 1) \times 32 = 896
\]

Here, 3x3 refers to the kernel size, 3 indicates the number of input channels (RGB), and the +1 accounts for the bias term, multiplied by the 32 filters.
answer_orig:
Let’s say we define our Conv2d layer like this:
>> tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(32, (3,3), activation='relu', input_shape=(150, 150, 3))
It means our input image is RGB (3 channels, 150 by 150 pixels), kernel is 3x3 and number of filters (layer’s width) is 32.
If we check model.summary() we will get this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
conv2d (Conv2D)             (None, 148, 148, 32)      896
So where does 896 params come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> (3*3*3 +1) * 32
896
# 3x3 kernel, 3 channels RGB, +1 for bias, 32 filters
What about the number of “features” we get after the Flatten layer?
For our homework model.summary() for last MaxPooling2d and Flatten layers looked like this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
max_pooling2d_3       (None, 7, 7, 128)         0
flatten (Flatten)           (None, 6272)              0
So where do 6272 vectors come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> 7*7*128
6272
# 7x7 “image shape” after several convolutions and poolings, 128 filters
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: What determines the parameter count for a Conv2d layer?

answer_llm:
The output shape of a Conv2D layer is derived based on the formula for calculating the output dimensions after applying convolution. In the example provided, the Conv2D layer is defined with a kernel size of (3, 3), 32 filters, and an input shape of (150, 150, 3).

The output shape can be calculated as follows:
1. **Height and Width Calculation**: The output height and width are determined by the formula:
   \[
   \text{Output Size} = \left( \frac{\text{Input Size} - \text{Kernel Size} + 2 \times \text{Padding}}{\text{Stride}} \right) + 1
   \]
   Assuming padding is 0 and stride is 1, for both height and width:
   \[
   \text{Output Height} = \left( \frac{150 - 3 + 0}{1} \right) + 1 = 148
   \]
   \[
   \text{Output Width} = \left( \frac{150 - 3 + 0}{1} \right) + 1 = 148
   \]

2. **Depth Calculation**: The output depth (number of filters) is equal to the number of filters defined in the layer, which is 32.

Putting it all together, the output shape of the Conv2D layer is (None, 148, 148, 32), where "None" indicates the batch size.

Thus, when checking `model.summary()`, it shows:
```
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
conv2d (Conv2D)             (None, 148, 148, 32)      896
```

question: How is the output shape of a Conv2d layer derived as shown in model.summary()?

answer_llm:
The Conv2d layer with 32 filters has 896 parameters because the calculation is as follows: 

Each filter has a size of 3x3 and operates on an RGB image, which has 3 channels. Thus, the number of parameters for each filter is calculated as:

\[
3 \text{ (height)} \times 3 \text{ (width)} \times 3 \text{ (channels)} + 1 \text{ (bias)} = 27 + 1 = 28
\]

Since there are 32 filters in this layer, the total number of parameters becomes:

\[
28 \times 32 = 896
\]

Therefore, the Conv2d layer with 32 filters has 896 parameters.

question: Why does the Conv2d layer with 32 filters have 896 parameters?

answer_llm:
To calculate the number of features after the Flatten layer, you multiply the dimensions of the output from the last MaxPooling2D layer. For example, if the output shape is (None, 7, 7, 128), you compute the number of features as follows: 

\[ 7 \times 7 \times 128 = 6272 \]

Thus, the number of features after the Flatten layer is 6272.

question: How do you calculate the number of features after the Flatten layer?

answer_llm:
The process to determine the 6272 vectors in the Flatten layer is calculated based on the output shape of the previous layer. Specifically, after several convolutions and poolings, the MaxPooling2D layer produces an output of shape (None, 7, 7, 128). The Flatten layer then takes this output and reshapes it into a 1D array. The number of vectors is computed by multiplying the dimensions of this output shape: 

\[ 7 \times 7 \times 128 = 6272 \] 

Thus, the Flatten layer results in 6272 vectors.

answer_llm: The main difference between the Sequential and Functional Model API in Keras is their structure and complexity. The Sequential Model API is simpler and consists of a plain stack of layers where each layer has one input tensor and one output tensor, allowing you to start with an "empty" model and add layers in a sequential order. In contrast, the Functional Model API is more advanced and allows for complex architectures, such as specifying multiple inputs and outputs or reusing layers. This might be more beneficial in scenarios like Transfer Learning where you want to differentiate between the base model and additional layers.
answer_orig:
It’s quite useful to understand that all types of models in the course are a plain stack of layers where each layer has exactly one input tensor and one output tensor (Sequential model TF page, Sequential class).
You can simply start from an “empty” model and add more and more layers in a sequential order.
This mode is called “Sequential Model API”  (easier)
In Alexey’s videos it is implemented as chained calls of different entities (“inputs”,“base”, “vectors”,  “outputs”) in a more advanced mode “Functional Model API”.
Maybe a more complicated way makes sense when you do Transfer Learning and want to separate “Base” model vs. rest, but in the HW you need to recreate the full model from scratch ⇒ I believe it is easier to work with a sequence of “similar” layers.
You can read more about it in this TF2 tutorial.
A really useful Sequential model example is shared in the Kaggle’s “Bee or Wasp” dataset folder with code: notebook
Added by Ivan Brigida
Fresh Run on Neural Nets
While correcting an error on neural net architecture, it is advised to do fresh run by restarting kernel, else the model learns on top of previous runs.
Added by Abhijit Chakraborty
question: What is the main difference between the Sequential and Functional Model API in Keras?

answer_llm: The Sequential Model API might be easier to use for beginners because it allows users to start from an “empty” model and add layers in a straightforward sequential order. This simplicity in building models, where each layer has exactly one input tensor and one output tensor, makes it more accessible for those new to deep learning. In contrast, the Functional Model API involves more complicated building processes with chained calls, which may be more challenging for beginners to grasp.

answer_llm:
When correcting an error on a neural net architecture, you should consider the following steps: 

1. Ensure that the correct data preprocessing steps have been applied, such as feature normalization and categorical feature encoding, if applicable.
2. Check if the appropriate class mode is set while reading the data, particularly if dealing with binary classification (set `class_mode='binary'`).
3. Review the choice of optimizer, batch size, and learning rate, as selecting the wrong configurations can lead to convergence issues.
4. If there are problems after data augmentation, verify that any data generators, such as the ImageDataGenerator, include necessary options like “rescale”.

By following these steps, you can address potential issues in the neural net architecture and improve its training process.

answer_llm:
To fix out of memory (OOM) errors in TensorFlow when using an Nvidia GPU, you can use the following code snippet at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
    pass
```

Alternatively, if you encounter allocator ran out of memory errors, you can add this code:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

Using either of these methods should help resolve the memory-related issues you are experiencing while working with TensorFlow on an Nvidia GPU.

question: What steps should I take to fix out of memory errors in TensorFlow when using an Nvidia GPU?

answer_llm:
To address out-of-memory (OOM) errors in TensorFlow when using a GPU, you can add the following code snippet to your notebook:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.experimental.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
    pass
```

This code enables memory growth for the GPU, which can help prevent OOM errors. If you're still experiencing OOM errors, you might consider using the following configuration as well:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This configuration may resolve most of your memory allocation issues during training.

answer_llm: The `tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth` function in TensorFlow is used to prevent out of memory (OOM) errors when running TensorFlow applications, particularly on systems with Nvidia GPUs. By enabling memory growth, TensorFlow will only allocate as much GPU memory as is currently needed for the runtime, instead of allocating all of the GPU memory at once. This can help manage memory more efficiently, especially when dealing with large models or datasets.

question: What is the purpose of the tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth function in TensorFlow?

answer_llm:
To handle an invalid device or an inability to modify virtual devices in TensorFlow, you can use the following code snippet to set memory growth for your GPU. This approach attempts to enable memory growth for the specified GPU device:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
    pass
```

This code attempts to modify the device settings, and if it encounters an invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices, it will gracefully pass without raising an error.

answer_llm: To speed up model training on Google Colab with a T4 GPU, you can specify the number of workers/threads in the fit function when training the models. By default, the number of workers is set to 1, which may result in slow training times. You can increase the workers variable to a higher value, such as 2560, to improve the training speed.
answer_orig:
When training the models, in the fit function, you can specify the number of workers/threads.
The number of threads apparently also works for GPUs, and came very handy in google colab for the T4 GPU, since it was very very slow, and workers default value is 1.
I changed the workers variable to 2560, following this thread in stackoverflow. I am using the free T4 GPU.  (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/68208398/how-to-find-the-number-of-cores-in-google-colabs-gpu)
Added by Ibai Irastorza
question: How can I speed up model training on Google Colab with a T4 GPU?

answer_llm: Your model training on Google Colab's T4 GPU may be very slow because the default value for the number of workers in the fit function is set to 1. To improve the training speed, you can increase the number of workers/threads. For example, you can change the workers variable to 2560, which has been helpful for some users when training models on the T4 GPU in Google Colab.

answer_llm: ImageDataGenerator is not recommended for new code in Keras because it has been deprecated. Instead, it is advised to use tf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory to load images and transform the output using preprocessing layers. This change aligns with updated practices in Keras for loading and augmenting images. For more information, you can refer to the tutorials related to image loading and augmentation, as well as the preprocessing layer guide.
answer_orig:
From the keras documentation:
Deprecated: tf.keras.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator is not recommended for new code. Prefer loading images with tf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory and transforming the output tf.data.Dataset with preprocessing layers. For more information, see the tutorials for loading images and augmenting images, as well as the preprocessing layer guide.
Hrithik Kumar Advani

answer_llm: When the command `echo ${REMOTE_URI}` returns nothing, it indicates that the `REMOTE_URI` variable is not set in the current terminal session. To resolve this, you need to set a local variable by assigning a valid URI address to `REMOTE_URI` in the terminal. For example, you can use a command like `REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images`, replacing the example address with your own. Keep in mind that this variable will be lost once the terminal session is terminated.
answer_orig:
Solution description
In the unit 9.6, Alexey ran the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} which turned the URI address in the terminal. There workaround is to set a local variable (REMOTE_URI) and assign your URI address in the terminal and use it to login the registry, for instance, REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images (fake address). One caveat is that you will lose this variable once the session is terminated.
I also had the same problem on Ubuntu terminal. I executed the following two commands:
$ export REMOTE_URI=1111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
$ echo $REMOTE_URI
111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
Note: 1. no curly brackets (e.g. echo ${REMOTE_URI}) needed unlike in video 9.6,
2. Replace REMOTE_URI with your URI
(Bhaskar Sarma)
question: What does it mean when the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} returns nothing?

answer_llm:
To set the `REMOTE_URI` variable to your URI address, you can use the following command in your terminal:

```bash
export REMOTE_URI=your_uri_address
```

Replace `your_uri_address` with your actual URI. For example:

```bash
export REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
```

After executing this command, you can verify it by running:

```bash
echo $REMOTE_URI
```

This should return your URI address. Remember that this variable will not persist after the session is terminated.

question: How do I set the REMOTE_URI variable to my URI address?

answer_llm:
If you lose the REMOTE_URI variable after the session ends, you will need to set the variable again in your terminal. You can do this by using the `export` command to assign your URI address to REMOTE_URI. For example:

```bash
export REMOTE_URI=your_uri_address
```

After executing this command, you can check if it’s set correctly by using:

```bash
echo $REMOTE_URI
```

Please note that you will lose this variable once the session is terminated, so you will need to repeat this process whenever you start a new session.

answer_llm:
The updated command to fetch the password from aws-cli is:

```bash
aws ecr get-login-password
```

This replaces the original command `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email`, which returns an invalid choice error. You can further simplify the login process by using the following commands, replacing `<ACCOUNT_NUMBER>` and `<REGION>` with your values:

```bash
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
```

question: What command should I use instead of aws ecr get-login --no-include-email to avoid syntax errors?

answer_llm:
To resolve the invalid choice error when using the command `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email`, you should use the following command instead:

```
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
```

Alternatively, if you have a default region configured, you can run this command without changing anything:

```
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
```

This change should help you successfully log in without encountering the invalid choice error.

answer_llm:
To log in to the AWS ECR for the `clothing-tflite-images` repository, use the following commands:

1. First, get the login password using:
   ```
   export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
   ```

2. Then, log in to Docker using this command (replace `<ACCOUNT_NUMBER>` and `<REGION>` with your specific AWS account number and region):
   ```
   docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
   ```

Make sure you have the AWS CLI configured with the appropriate permissions to access the ECR.

The ERROR [internal] load metadata for public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.8 is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image. To resolve this issue, you can try the following solutions:

1. Update your Docker Desktop if you haven’t done so.
2. Restart Docker Desktop and terminal, then attempt to build the image again.
3. If the problem persists, run the command: `DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0 docker build .` to build your image.
answer_orig:
This error is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
Solution description: The following could solve the problem.
Update your docker desktop if you haven’t done so.
Or restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again.
Or if all else fails, first run the following command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0  docker build .  then build your image.
(optional) Added by Odimegwu David

question: What should I do if I see 'Windows version might not be up-to-date' when running a Docker build command?

answer_llm: To address the error 'The system cannot find the file specified' in Docker on Windows, you should check that the Dockerfile is correctly named without an extension (it should just be "Dockerfile"). If the issue persists, you might need to review your Python installation and environment variables, particularly ensuring that the required Python version is added to the PATH. question: How do I address the error 'The system cannot find the file specified' in Docker on Windows?

answer_llm: The error message 'docker daemon is not running' indicates that the Docker client cannot connect to the Docker daemon, which is necessary for executing Docker commands. To resolve this issue, you may need to start the Docker daemon using commands like `sudo dockerd` or `sudo service docker start` on Linux. Additionally, if you are using WSL, you might need to reinstall Docker or ensure that Docker Desktop is installed on your host machine.

answer_llm:
Your lambda function may pass local tests but fail on a running Docker instance due to serialization issues with the response. Specifically, when your model returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 types, they must be converted to base-Python floats to be JSON serializable. If you encounter an error like "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable," it indicates that you need to convert these values. For example, instead of directly returning the float32 values, you should convert them using `float()` like this:

```python
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
         float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
```

This conversion ensures that the values can be properly serialized when your lambda function is executed within the Docker instance.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While passing local testing of the lambda function without issues, trying to test the same input with a running docker instance results in an error message like
{‘errorMessage’: ‘Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable’, ‘errorType’: ‘Runtime.MarshalError’, ‘requestId’: ‘f155492c-9af2-4d04-b5a4-639548b7c7ac’, ‘stackTrace’: []}
This happens when a model (in this case the dino vs dragon model) returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays). They need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become “serializable”.
Solution:
In my particular case, I set up the dino vs dragon model in such a way as to return a label + predicted probability for each class as follows (below is a two-line extract of function predict() in the lambda_function.py):
preds = [interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0], \
1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]]
In which case the above described solution will look like this:
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
The rest can be made work by following the chapter 9 (and/or chapter 5!) lecture videos step by step.
Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: Why does my lambda function pass local tests but fail on a running docker instance?

answer_llm:

These numpy float32 values must be converted to base-Python float types to be JSON serializable. For example, instead of returning numpy float32 values, you should convert them in your code like this:

```python
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
         float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
```

This conversion is necessary to prevent the serialization error when attempting to marshal the response.

```python
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), 
         float(1 - interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
```

This conversion ensures that the float32 values become JSON serializable.

answer_llm:
To resolve lambda function errors in serverless deep learning, you should refer to the content from Section 9, specifically:

1. For understanding how to test AWS Lambda + Docker and troubleshoot errors, refer to the answer regarding using AWS RIE and the example curl commands. This includes handling errors like JSON serialization issues by converting your result to a string in the `lambda_handler()`.

2. For the import error "Unable to import module 'lambda_function': No module named 'tensorflow'", ensure to change your import statement from `import tensorflow.lite as tflite` to `import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite` if you are not relying on the TensorFlow library.

These insights are key to troubleshooting common lambda function errors in your serverless deep learning projects.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While passing local testing of the lambda function without issues, trying to test the same input with a running docker instance results in an error message like
{‘errorMessage’: ‘Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable’, ‘errorType’: ‘Runtime.MarshalError’, ‘requestId’: ‘f155492c-9af2-4d04-b5a4-639548b7c7ac’, ‘stackTrace’: []}
This happens when a model (in this case the dino vs dragon model) returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays). They need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become “serializable”.
Solution:
In my particular case, I set up the dino vs dragon model in such a way as to return a label + predicted probability for each class as follows (below is a two-line extract of function predict() in the lambda_function.py):
preds = [interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0], \
1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]]
In which case the above described solution will look like this:
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
The rest can be made work by following the chapter 9 (and/or chapter 5!) lecture videos step by step.
Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: Which chapters and videos should I refer to for resolving lambda function errors in serverless deep learning?

answer_llm:
The error when running the command `interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x)` is caused by a mismatch in the expected data type. Specifically, it raises a `ValueError` indicating that it received a value of type `UINT8` while it was expecting a type of `FLOAT32` for the input. This typically happens when the variable `x` is of type `int` instead of the required `float`. 

To resolve this issue, you need to convert `x` to `float32` before calling `set_tensor`. You can do this by using the following code:

```python
x = np.float32(x)
```

After this conversion, the command should work correctly.
answer_orig:
I had this error when running the command line : interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x) that can be seen in the video 9.3 around 12 minutes.
ValueError: Cannot set tensor: Got value of type UINT8 but expected type FLOAT32 for input 0, name: serving_default_conv2d_input:0
This is because the X is an int but a float is expected.
Solution:
I found this solution from this question here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/76102508/valueerror-cannot-set-tensor-got-value-of-type-float64-but-expected-type-float :
# Need to convert to float32 before set_tensor
X = np.float32(X)
Then, it works. I work with tensorflow 2.15.0, maybe the fact that this version is more recent involves this change ?
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

answer_llm:
To check the size of a file using the PowerShell terminal, you can use the following command lines:

1. Assign the file to a variable:
   ```powershell
   $File = Get-Item -Path path_to_file
   ```

2. Get the file size:
   ```powershell
   $FileSize = (Get-Item -Path $FilePath).Length
   ```

3. To display the size in MB:
   ```powershell
   Write-host "MB":($FileSize/1MB)
   ``` 

Replace `path_to_file` and `$FilePath` with the actual path to your file.

Now you can check the size of your file, for example in MB:

Source: https://www.sharepointdiary.com/2020/10/powershell-get-file-size.html#:~:text=To%20get%20the%20size%20of,the%20file%2C%20including%20its%20size.

answer_llm:
To create and push a Docker image for AWS Lambda, you need to follow these general steps:

1. **Build Your Docker Image**: Start by creating a Dockerfile that uses the base AWS Lambda image, for example, `FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10`.

2. **Build Locally**: You can build your Docker image using the command:
   ```
   docker build -t your-image-name .
   ```

3. **Test Locally**: Optionally, you can test the Docker image locally using the AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator) with the following command:
   ```
   docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 your-image-name
   ```
   This will start an endpoint locally at `http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations`.

4. **Authenticate and Push to ECR**: Before pushing the image to Amazon ECR, you need to authenticate your Docker client to your Amazon ECR registry using:
   ```
   aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
   ```
   Replace the placeholders with your actual AWS region and account ID.

5. **Tag Your Image**: Tag your Docker image for your ECR repository:
   ```
   docker tag your-image-name:latest aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com/your-repo-name:tag
   ```

6. **Push Your Image**: Finally, push the image to ECR with:
   ```
   docker push aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com/your-repo-name:tag
   ```

Make sure to refer to the AWS documentation for additional details on Lambda and Docker integration.

answer_llm:
To resolve the pip install error when building a Docker image in Section 9.5 on an M1 Mac, you should use the following command to build the Docker image:

```bash
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
```

This command targets the x86_64 architecture, which helps to avoid compatibility issues related to the ARM architecture of the M1 chip. Additionally, make sure to use the corrected URL for the tflite runtime wheel if needed:

```plaintext
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl
```

If you continue to experience issues, it may be necessary to run the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While trying to build docker image in Section 9.5 with the command:
docker build -t clothing-model .

Try to use this link: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl

Or try the code bellow.

question: How do I resolve a pip install error when building a Docker image in Section 9.5 on an M1 Mac?

   [https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl](https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl).

2. Alternatively, since the error might be due to the ARM architecture of the M1, consider building the Docker image with the following command to ensure compatibility:


3. When running the built image, use the command:
   ```
   docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest
   ```

If these solutions do not resolve the issue, you may need to run the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS.

answer_llm:
To address issues caused by the arm architecture of the M1 when building Docker images in Section 9, you can use the following approaches:

1. **Use a different platform flag**: When building the Docker image, run the command with the platform specified as `linux/amd64`:
   ```
   docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
   ```

2. **Run the built image with the same platform specification**:
   ```
   docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest
   ```

3. If you encounter pip install errors, particularly with specific wheels, ensure you are using the correct download link or try running the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS instead.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the issues caused by the M1 architecture.

Problem:
While trying to build docker image in Section 9.5 with the command:
docker build -t clothing-model .
It throws a pip install error for the tflite runtime whl
ERROR: failed to solve: process "/bin/sh -c pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/blob/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl" did not complete successfully: exit code: 1
Try to use this link: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl
If the link above does not work:
The problem is because of the arm architecture of the M1. You will need to run the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS.
Or try the code bellow.
Added by Dashel Ruiz Perez
Solution:
To build the Docker image, use the command:
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
To run the built image, use the command:
docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest
Added by Daniel Egbo
question: How can I address issues caused by the arm architecture of the M1 when building Docker images in Section 9?

answer_llm:
To build and run a Docker image on an M1 Mac for Section 9.5 tasks, you should use the following commands:

To build the Docker image:
```
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
```

To run the built image:
```
docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest
```

answer_llm:
If you encounter the error "Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime," it may be because the specific version you are trying to install does not support your current Python version (e.g., Python 3.10). To resolve this, you can try the following steps:

1. **Install Python 3.9**: The tflite_runtime is known to work well with Python 3.9. After installing Python 3.9, you should be able to install tflite_runtime without issues.

2. **Check Compatibility**: Visit [this link](https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/) to see all available versions of tflite_runtime and verify if your OS and Python version are supported.

3. **Alternative Installation**: If you don't find a compatible version, you can try using an alternative available at [this GitHub repository](https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite). You can install it using the command shown in the lecture:
   ```bash
   pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
   ```

4. **Use TensorFlow's TFLite**: If nothing works, consider using the TFLite version included in TensorFlow for local development and Docker for testing Lambda functions.

By following these steps, you should be able to resolve the installation issue with tflite_runtime.
answer_orig:
Problem: When trying to install tflite_runtime with
!pip install --extra-index-url https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/ tflite_runtime
one gets an error message above.
Solution:
fflite_runtime is only available for the os-python version combinations that can be found here: https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
your combination must be missing here
you can see if any of these work for you https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
and install the needed one using pip
eg

https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/mlbookcamp-code/blob/master/course-zoomcamp/09-serverless/code/Dockerfile#L4
Alternatively, use a virtual machine (with VM VirtualBox, for example) with a Linux system. The other way is to run a code at a virtual machine within cloud service, for example you can use Vertex AI Workbench at GCP (notebooks and terminals are provided there, so all tasks may be performed).

question: Where can I check compatible OS-Python version combinations for tflite_runtime?

answer_llm:
To install a specific version of `tflite_runtime` using pip, you can follow these steps:

1. Ensure you have Python 3.9, as `tflite_runtime` does not run on Python 3.10.
2. Check the available versions of `tflite_runtime` at the following link: [TFLite Runtime Versions](https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/).
3. If the right version for your setup is not found there, you can try using a version from the GitHub repository. For example, you can install a specific version using the command:

   ```bash
   pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
   ```

Make sure to replace the URL with the version of `tflite_runtime` that is compatible with your setup.

question: Is there a sample Dockerfile demonstrating the installation of tflite_runtime for this course?

answer_llm:
If you cannot install `tflite_runtime` on your current system, you have several alternatives:

1. **Use Python 3.9**: The current version of `tflite_runtime` does not run on Python 3.10. Installing Python 3.9 should allow you to install `tflite_runtime` without issues.

2. **Check Available Versions**: You can check all available versions of `tflite_runtime` at [this link](https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/).

3. **Alternative Installation**: If you don’t find a suitable version, you can try to install it from a different repository, such as [this one](https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite), using a command like:
   ```
   pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
   ```

4. **Use TensorFlow**: If nothing else works, consider using the TFLite that comes with TensorFlow for local development.

5. **Virtual Machines**: You can run a virtual machine with a Linux system using a tool like VM VirtualBox, or utilize cloud services such as Vertex AI Workbench on GCP, which provides notebooks and terminals for your tasks.

answer_llm:
To save a Docker image to your local machine, you can use the following command to export the image to a tar file:

```bash
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
```

After saving the image, you can view the individual layers of the Docker image by extracting the `layer.tar` present in the `<name-of-tar-file.tar>` that you created.
answer_orig:
The docker image can be saved/exported to tar format in local machine using the below command:
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
The individual layers of the docker image for the filesystem content can be viewed by extracting the layer.tar present in the <name-of-tar-file.tar> created from above.
Sumeet Lalla

question: What command allows exporting a Docker image to tar format?

answer_llm:
To view the contents of a Docker image saved as a tar file, you need to first save/export the Docker image to a tar format using the command:

```
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
```

Once you have the tar file, you can extract the contents to view the individual layers of the Docker image. Specifically, you need to extract the `layer.tar` file present within the `<name-of-tar-file.tar>` to see the filesystem content.

answer_llm: If a Jupyter notebook doesn't recognize a package you just installed, you can try restarting the Jupyter notebook. For example, after installing a package like pillow using `pip install pillow`, the imports may work correctly after a restart.

On vscode running jupyter notebook. After I ‘pip install pillow’, my notebook did not recognize using the import for example from PIL import image. After restarting the jupyter notebook the imports worked.
Quinn Avila
question: What can I do if a Jupyter notebook doesn't recognize a package I just installed?

answer_llm:
To fix import errors in a Jupyter notebook after using pip install, try the following steps:

1. If the import error occurs after installing a package, restart your Jupyter notebook. For example, after installing a package like Pillow, you need to restart the notebook for the imports to work.

2. If you are encountering specific import errors related to environmental conflicts (such as with Jinja2), switch to the main environment and run the command: `pip install nbconvert --upgrade`.

These steps should help resolve the import errors in your notebook.

answer_llm:
If the command `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email` gives an invalid choice error, you should instead use the command `aws ecr get-login-password`. This will allow you to log in without encountering that error. Optionally, you can simplify the login process by using the following command, replacing `<ACCOUNT_NUMBER>` and `<REGION>` with your actual values:

```bash
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
```

question: What is the solution for aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice in Serverless Deep Learning?

answer_llm:
If `aws ecr get-login` returns an invalid choice error, you should use the command `aws ecr get-login-password` instead. Additionally, to simplify the login process, you can use the following commands, replacing `<ACCOUNT_NUMBER>` and `<REGION>` with your values:

```bash
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
```

Alternatively, you can run the command without changing anything if you have a default region configured:

```bash
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
```

answer_llm:
To create a new IAM policy, follow these steps:

1. **Sign in to the AWS Console**: Log in to the AWS Console.
2. **Navigate to IAM**: Go to the IAM service by clicking on "Services" in the top left corner and selecting "IAM" under the "Security, Identity, & Compliance" section.
3. **Create a new policy**: In the left navigation pane, select "Policies" and click on "Create policy."
4. **Select the service and actions**: Click on "JSON" and copy and paste the desired JSON policy.
5. **Review and create the policy**:
   - Click on "Review policy."
   - Provide a name and description for the policy.
   - Click on "Create policy." 

An example JSON policy is as follows:

```json
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Sid": "VisualEditor0",
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": [
        "ecr:CreateRepository",
        "ecr:GetAuthorizationToken",
        "ecr:BatchCheckLayerAvailability",
        "ecr:BatchGetImage",
        "ecr:InitiateLayerUpload",
        "ecr:UploadLayerPart",
        "ecr:CompleteLayerUpload",
        "ecr:PutImage"
      ],
      "Resource": "*"
    }
  ]
}
```

If you encounter a Docker Temporary failure in name resolution during the Serverless Deep Learning section, you should add the following lines to the file `/etc/docker/daemon.json`:

```json
{
  "dns": ["8.8.8.8", "8.8.4.4"]
}
```

After making this change, restart Docker using the command:

```bash
sudo service docker restart
```

To fix the error "weight_decay is not a valid argument" when loading a Keras model, you should add `compile=False` to the `load_model` function. Use the following code:

```python
keras.models.load_model('model_name.h5', compile=False)
```

answer_llm:
To test AWS Lambda with Docker locally, you need to use AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator). Here are the steps to set it up:

1. Ensure your Docker image is based on the AWS Lambda image, using a command like `FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10`.
2. Run the image with the following command:
   ```
   docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
   ```
   This command will start an endpoint locally at `localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations`.

3. To test the function, you can use the following curl command:
   ```
   curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
   ```

For specific examples, you can use the below commands based on your operating system:

- **Windows testing**:
  ```
  curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{\"url\": \"https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg\"}"
  ```

- **Unix testing**:
  ```
  curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
  ```

If you encounter an error related to JSON serialization, ensure that your response in `lambda_handler()` is a string by converting it using `str(result)`.
answer_orig:
This deployment setup can be tested locally using AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator).
Basically, if your Docker image was built upon base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10) - just use certain ports for “docker run” and a certain “localhost link” for testing:
docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
This command runs the image as a container and starts up an endpoint locally at:
localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations
Post an event to the following endpoint using a curl command:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
Examples of curl testing:
* windows testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{\"url\": \"https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg\"}"
* unix testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
If during testing you encounter an error like this:
# {"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError", "requestId": "7ea5d17a-e0a2-48d5-b747-a16fc530ed10", "stackTrace": []}
just turn your response at lambda_handler() to string - str(result).
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: What setup is needed to test AWS Lambda with Docker locally?

answer_llm:
To run the Docker image as a container for AWS Lambda, you can use the following command, provided your Docker image was built on the base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10):

```bash
docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
```

This command will start the image as a container and set up an endpoint locally accessible at:

```
localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations
```

You can test the setup by posting an event to the endpoint using a curl command like this:

```bash
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
```

Make sure to adjust the curl data payload based on your requirements.

# {"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError", "requestId": "7ea5d17a-e0a2-48d5-b747-a16fc530ed10", "stackTrace": []}
just turn your response at lambda_handler() to string - str(result).

question: What is the command to post an event to the AWS Lambda endpoint?

answer_llm:
Yes, there are specific `curl` commands for testing AWS Lambda locally in Unix. You can use the following command to post an event to your locally running AWS Lambda function:

```bash
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
```

Make sure that your Docker image is running with the appropriate setup, and the function is accessible at the specified localhost endpoint.
answer_orig:
This deployment setup can be tested locally using AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator).
Basically, if your Docker image was built upon base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10) - just use certain ports for “docker run” and a certain “localhost link” for testing:
docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
This command runs the image as a container and starts up an endpoint locally at:
localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations
Post an event to the following endpoint using a curl command:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
Examples of curl testing:
* windows testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{\"url\": \"https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg\"}"
* unix testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
If during testing you encounter an error like this:
# {"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError", "requestId": "7ea5d17a-e0a2-48d5-b747-a16fc530ed10", "stackTrace": []}
just turn your response at lambda_handler() to string - str(result).
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: Are there any specific curl commands for testing AWS Lambda locally in Unix?

answer_llm:
If you encounter a JSON serialization error during local AWS Lambda testing, such as the error message `{"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError"}`, you should convert the float32 values to base-Python floats. 

Specifically, in your `lambda_handler()` function, ensure that you return the response as a string with `str(result)`, and if your model returns numpy float32 values (arrays), convert them individually using `float()`. For example:

```python
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
```

This conversion will make the values serializable as JSON.

answer_llm: The error 'Unable to import module 'lambda_function': No module named 'tensorflow'' occurs when there are dependencies on the TensorFlow library in your code. A common reason for this error is if you are importing TensorFlow Lite from TensorFlow. To resolve this, change the import statement from `import tensorflow.lite as tflite` to `import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite`. Make sure none of the code in `test.py` relies on the TensorFlow library.

To install Docker (udocker) in Google Colab to work with TensorFlow Serving, you can follow these steps:

1. Install udocker by running the command:
   ```bash
   !pip install udocker
   ```

2. Initialize udocker with the command:
   ```bash
   !udocker --allow-root install
   ```

3. You can then run Docker containers using udocker. For example, to run a hello-world container, use:
   ```bash
   !udocker --allow-root run hello-world
   ```

For detailed instructions and additional information, you can refer to the following link: [Udocker Installation in Google Colab](https://gist.github.com/mwufi/6718b30761cd109f9aff04c5144eb885).

answer_llm:
If you are unable to run `pip install tflite_runtime` from GitHub wheel links, you can try the following solutions:

1. Check the available OS-Python version combinations for `tflite_runtime` here: [https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/](https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/). If your combination is not listed, it means it is not supported.

2. If you can't find a matching version, you can explore the options available in this repository: [https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite](https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite) and install an appropriate `.whl` file using pip, for example:
   ```
   pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
   ```

3. Alternatively, consider switching to a virtual machine with a Linux system, such as using VM VirtualBox, or you can utilize a cloud service like Vertex AI Workbench at GCP.

4. Lastly, if none of the above options work, you can use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development and utilize Docker for testing Lambda.

To install TensorFlow with CUDA support in WSL2, you need to meet the following prerequisites:

1. **Hardware**: Ensure you have the right hardware that supports CUDA.
2. **NVIDIA Drivers**: Install the appropriate Windows NVIDIA drivers. 
3. **CUDA Toolkit**: Install CUDA toolkit version 11.x.x.
4. **cuDNN**: Install cuDNN from the NVIDIA developer site.
5. **TensorFlow Installation**: Use either the TensorFlow installation method or an Anaconda package to install TensorFlow with GPU support. Follow the guidelines specifically for WSL/Linux installation, making sure to adhere to step 4 for environment configuration related to CUDA.

Make sure you have everything configured correctly to enable GPU training/inference with TensorFlow.
answer_orig:
Running a CNN on your CPU can take a long time and once you’ve run out of free time on some cloud providers, it’s time to pay up. Both can be tackled by installing tensorflow with CUDA support on your local machine if you have the right hardware.
I was able to get it working by using the following resources:
CUDA on WSL :: CUDA Toolkit Documentation (nvidia.com)
Install TensorFlow with pip
Start Locally | PyTorch
I included the link to PyTorch so that you can get that one installed and working too while everything is fresh on your mind. Just select your options, and for Computer Platform, I chose CUDA 11.7 and it worked for me.
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm:
If you get "Allocator ran out of memory" errors while running TensorFlow on your machine, try adding the following code at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

Doing this resolved most of the issues for others, although there may still be occasional errors. In one instance, the error occurred again during a single epoch, but it disappeared when the code was run again afterward.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: What should I do if I get Allocator ran out of memory errors while running TensorFlow on my machine?

answer_llm:
To configure TensorFlow and address memory allocation issues on your machine, you can use the following code snippet at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This should help prevent out of memory errors by allowing TensorFlow to dynamically allocate memory instead of allocating all memory at once. Although it may not resolve every issue (as there could be rare instances when errors still occur), it has worked for many users. Additionally, if you are using an Nvidia GPU, you can also try the following code to set memory growth on the GPU:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    pass
```

These configurations should help manage memory allocation more effectively while running TensorFlow.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I configure TensorFlow to solve memory allocation issues on my machine?

answer_llm:
To help with performance gains if you encounter memory errors in TensorFlow, you can configure TensorFlow to allow memory growth on the GPU. You can do this by adding the following code at the beginning of your notebook:

```python
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

This adjustment allows TensorFlow to allocate memory for the GPU dynamically as needed, which may alleviate memory issues.

answer_llm:
In session 10.3, when creating the virtual environment with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might encounter the following error:

**TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.**

This error occurs if the generated code from a _pb2.py file is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc version 3.19.0 or higher. If you cannot regenerate your protos immediately, you can try one of the following workarounds:

1. Downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`, although this will use pure-Python parsing and will be significantly slower. 

This issue is linked to using a newer version of the protobuf package.
answer_orig:
In session 10.3, when creating the virtual environment with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might get this error:
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
More information: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/news/2022-05-06#python-updates
This will happen if your version of protobuf is one of the newer ones. As a workaround, you can fix the protobuf version to an older one. In my case I got around the issue by creating the environment with:
pipenv install --python 3.9.13 requests grpcio==1.42.0 flask gunicorn \
keras-image-helper tensorflow-protobuf==2.7.0 protobuf==3.19.6
Added by Ángel de Vicente
question: What error might occur when creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and running gateway.py?

answer_llm:
To resolve the TypeError issue caused by the recent version of protobuf in session 10.3, you can take the following steps:

1. **Downgrade the protobuf package**: You can downgrade your protobuf version to 3.20.x or lower. For example, you can use the following command to install protobuf version 3.20.1:
   ```
   pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
   ```

2. **Set the environment variable**: If you cannot immediately downgrade the protobuf version or regenerate your protos, you can set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION` to `python`. However, be aware that this will use pure-Python parsing, which will be much slower:
   ```
   export PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python
   ```

If your code generates protobuf from `.proto` files, ensure that you regenerate the code with `protoc >= 3.19.0`.

answer_llm:
If you encounter the error message "Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?" in WSL, you can try the following solutions:

1. Check Docker Desktop settings: The Docker Desktop might not be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. Go to your Docker Desktop settings, click on resources, then WSL Integration, and enable additional distros. This could include the same default WSL distro.

2. If you're still having issues, consider reinstalling Docker. Remove the Docker installation from WSL and install Docker Desktop on your host machine (Windows).

3. Alternatively, if you're using Linux instead of WSL, try starting the docker daemon with one of these commands:
   - `sudo dockerd`
   - `sudo service docker start` 

These steps should help you establish a connection to the Docker daemon on WSL.
answer_orig:
Due to the uncertainties associated with machines, sometimes you can get the error message like this when you try to run a docker command:
”Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?”
Solution: The solution is simple. The Docker Desktop might no longer be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. What you need to do is go to your Docker Desktop setting and then click on resources. Under resources, click on WSL Integration. You will get a tab like the image below:
Just enable additional distros. That’s all. Even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.
Odimegwu David
question: What should I do if WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon?

answer_llm:
To resolve the error: 'Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?', you can follow these steps based on your environment:

1. **For WSL (Windows Subsystem for Linux)**:
   - Ensure that Docker Desktop is properly installed and running on your host machine (Windows).
   - Check the Docker Desktop settings: Go to your Docker Desktop settings, click on 'Resources', and then 'WSL Integration'. Ensure that you enable the additional distros that you are using.

2. **For Linux**:
   - Start the Docker daemon by using one of the following commands:
     - `sudo dockerd`
     - `sudo service docker start`

Following these steps should help you connect to the Docker daemon successfully.

answer_llm:
If the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server, you can try the following solutions:

1. **Edit the Metrics Server Deployment**:
   - Run the command:
     ```
     kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
     ```
   - Search for this line:
     ```
     args:
     - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
     ```
   - Add this line in the middle:
     ```
     - --kubelet-insecure-tls
     ```
   - The args should now look like this:
     ```
     args:
     - --kubelet-insecure-tls
     - --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
     ```
   - Save the changes and then run:
     ```
     kubectl get hpa
     ```

2. **Use a Pre-Configured Metrics Server Deployment**:
   - Alternatively, you can apply a metrics server deployment file that already includes the `--kubelet-insecure-tls` option:
     ```
     kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml
     ```

These steps should help resolve the issue with the HPA instance.
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela

```

   kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml
   ``` 

Both methods should help resolve the issue of targets appearing as <unknown>.

>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run the following command:
kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml
Which uses a metrics server deployment file already embedding the - --kubelet-insecure-tls option.
Added by Giovanni Pecoraro

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied' error when installing libraries in Windows, consider using the `--user` option with your pip install command. For example, you can run:

```
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0
```

This approach helps by installing the packages in your user directory, avoiding permission issues.
answer_orig:
When I run pip install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0 to install the libraries in windows machine,  I was getting the below error :
ERROR: Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied: 'C:\\Users\\Asia\\anaconda3\\Lib\\site-packages\\google\\protobuf\\internal\\_api_implementation.cp39-win_amd64.pyd'
Consider using the `--user` option or check the permissions.
Solution description :
I was able to install the libraries using below command:
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0
