answer_llm:
The error that occurs when running gateway.py after modifying the code in video 10.3 is:

```
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
```

This is due to the version of the protobuf package being out of date or incompatible with the generated code, and it suggests that the generated code must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0. To resolve this, you can downgrade the protobuf package to a version 3.20.x or lower or set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`.
answer_orig:
Problem description
I was getting the below error message when I run gateway.py after modifying the code & creating virtual environment in  video 10.3 :
File "C:\Users\Asia\Data_Science_Code\Zoompcamp\Kubernetes\gat.py", line 9, in <module>
from tensorflow_serving.apis import predict_pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow_serving\apis\predict_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import tensor_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_tensor__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\tensor_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import resource_handle_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_resource__handle__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\resource_handle_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import tensor_shape_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_tensor__shape__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\tensor_shape_pb2.py", line 36, in <module>
_descriptor.FieldDescriptor(
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\google\protobuf\descriptor.py", line 560, in __new__
_message.Message._CheckCalledFromGeneratedFile()
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
Solution description:
Issue has been resolved by downgrading protobuf to version 3.20.1.
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1

question: What error occurs when running gateway.py after modifying the code in video 10.3?

answer_llm: The TypeError: "Descriptors cannot not be created directly" occurs when your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc version 3.19.0 or higher. This error appears after running the `gateway.py` script if the version of the protobuf package is one of the newer ones. You can resolve this issue by either downgrading the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower or setting `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`, though the latter will lead to slower performance due to using pure-Python parsing.

question: What causes the TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly?

answer_llm:
To resolve the issue of your generated protobuf code being out of date, you should regenerate your code using `protoc` version 3.19.0 or higher. If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, here are some alternative workarounds:

1. Downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set the environment variable `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`, but note that this will use pure-Python parsing, which is significantly slower.

For example, you can downgrade protobuf by running the command:
```
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
```
Make sure to check the compatibility of your protobuf version with your project to avoid further issues.

answer_llm:
To install kubectl easily on Windows, you can follow these steps:

1. Use the terminal in Visual Studio Code (PowerShell).
2. Download kubectl using the curl command by following the instructions in this tutorial: [Install kubectl on Windows](https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff).
3. Refer to the kubectl installation guide, specifically for Windows, to download the binary with curl: [Install kubectl binary with curl on Windows](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows).
4. After downloading, move the executable file to a specific folder on the C drive.
5. Add the folder path to your PATH in the environment variables.

This process will set up kubectl on your Windows system.
answer_orig:
To install kubectl on windows using the terminal in vscode (powershell), I followed this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff
I first downloaded kubectl with curl, with these command lines: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows
At step 3, I followed the tutorial with the copy of the exe file in a specific folder on C drive.
Then I added this folder path to PATH in my environment variables.
Kind can be installed the same way with the curl command on windows, by specifying a folder that will be added to the path environment variable.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

2. Copy the downloaded kubectl executable file to a specific folder on the C drive.

answer_llm:
To install Kind using Choco, you need to follow these steps:

1. Launch a PowerShell terminal with administrator privileges.
2. Install the Choco library by executing the following command in PowerShell:
   ```
   Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process -Force; [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor 3072; iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://chocolatey.org/install.ps1'))
   ```

After installing Choco, you can use it to install Kind.

answer_llm:
If you are having issues installing Kind through Windows Powershell and the Choco Library, you can install Kind using the Go package instead. Here are the steps you can follow:

1. Download and Install Go from the official site: [Go Installation Guide](https://go.dev/doc/install).
2. Confirm that Go is installed by typing the following command in Command Prompt: `go version`.
3. Then, install Kind by running the command: `go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0`.
4. Finally, confirm the installation by checking the version with the command: `kind --version`.

This method should work perfectly for you.

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl, you can try the following steps:

1. Delete the current Kubernetes cluster using the command:
   ```
   kind delete cluster
   ```

2. Remove the existing kube configuration directory:
   ```
   rm -rf ~/.kube
   ```

3. Create a new Kubernetes cluster:
   ```
   kind create cluster
   ```

After these steps, try running your kubectl command again.
answer_orig:
I ran into an issue where kubectl wasn't working.
I kept getting the following error:
kubectl get service
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?
I searched online for a resolution, but everyone kept talking about creating an environment variable and creating some admin.config file in my home directory.
All hogwash.
The solution to my problem was to just start over.
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
Now when I try the same command again:
kubectl get service
NAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
kubernetes   ClusterIP   10.96.0.1    <none>        443/TCP   53s
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl?

answer_llm:
To fix the kubectl server connection issue, Martin Uribe took the following steps:

1. He deleted the existing kind cluster using the command:
   ```
   kind delete cluster
   ```

2. He removed the `.kube` directory to ensure a clean configuration:
   ```
   rm -rf ~/.kube
   ```

3. He created a new kind cluster with the command:
   ```
   kind create cluster
   ```

After completing these steps, he was able to run the command `kubectl get service` successfully.

answer_llm:
To solve the issue of running out of storage after building many Docker images, you should follow these steps:

1. First, identify the Docker images taking up space by running the command:
   ```
   docker images
   ```

2. Remove any unnecessary or duplicate images using the command:
   ```
   docker rmi <image_name>
   ```

3. Note that simply removing Docker images might not immediately free up space. To actually reclaim the space, you need to run:
   ```
   docker system prune
   ```

This process will help you clear up storage on your system effectively.
answer_orig:
Problem description
Due to experimenting back and forth so much without care for storage, I just ran out of it on my 30-GB AWS instance.
My first reflex was to remove some zoomcamp directories, but of course those are mostly code so it didn’t help much.
Solution description
> docker images
revealed that I had over 20 GBs worth of superseded / duplicate models lying around, so I proceeded to > docker rmi
a bunch of those — but to no avail!
It turns out that deleting docker images does not actually free up any space as you might expect. After removing images, you also need to run
> docker system prune
See also: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36799718/why-removing-docker-containers-and-images-does-not-free-up-storage-space-on-wind
Added by Konrad Mühlberg
question: How can I solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images?

answer_llm: Removing some zoomcamp directories didn't help in freeing up space because those directories primarily contain code, which does not take up significant storage compared to the actual storage consumed by Docker images. After attempting to remove images, it was discovered that simply deleting Docker images does not free up space; one must also run `docker system prune` to actually reclaim that storage space.

answer_llm: In Kubernetes resource specifications, the "m" in values like "100m" and "500m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core. For example, "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, equivalent to 0.1 CPU core, while "500m" indicates a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs or 0.5 CPU core. Using milliCPUs allows for more granular control over CPU resource allocation.
answer_orig:
In Kubernetes resource specifications, such as CPU requests and limits, the "m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core.
cpu: "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.1 CPU core.
cpu: "500m" means the container has a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.5 CPU core.
These values are specified in milliCPUs to allow fine-grained control over CPU resources. It allows you to express CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, especially in scenarios where your application might not need a full CPU core.
Added by Andrii Larkin

answer_llm:
If your kind cluster can't find any nodes after loading a Docker image, you should specify the cluster name using the `-n` option. For example, use the command:

```
kind -n <your-cluster-name> load docker-image <your-image>
```

Replace `<your-cluster-name>` with the name of your cluster and `<your-image>` with the name of the Docker image you are trying to load.
answer_orig:
Problem: Failing to load docker-image to cluster (when you’ved named a cluster)
kind load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
ERROR: no nodes found for cluster "kind"
Solution: Specify cluster name with -n
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
Andrew Katoch
question: What should I do if my kind cluster can't find any nodes after loading a Docker image?

answer_llm:
To resolve the error 'no nodes found for cluster kind' when loading a Docker image using kind, you need to specify the cluster name using the `-n` flag. For example, you can use the following command:

```
kind -n [your-cluster-name] load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
```

Replace `[your-cluster-name]` with the actual name of your cluster.

question: How can I specify the cluster name when loading a Docker image with kind?

answer_llm:
Yes, there is a way to troubleshoot failure in loading a Docker image to a kind cluster. If you encounter the error "no nodes found for cluster 'kind'" when trying to load the Docker image, you should specify the cluster name using the `-n` flag. For example, you can use the following command:

```bash
kind -n <cluster-name> load docker-image <image-name>
```

In your case, if your cluster is named "clothing-model" and your image is "zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001", the command would be:

```bash
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
```

answer_llm: If 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command on Windows, you may need to rename the downloaded executable file. The default name is kind-windows-amd64.exe; you should rename this file to kind.exe. After renaming, place the file in a specific folder and add that folder to your PATH.

question: What should I do if 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command on Windows?

You need to rename this file to "kind.exe", place it in a specific folder, and add that folder to your PATH environment variable to resolve the issue.

question: Why am I getting the error 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command after downloading kind?

answer_llm:
To resolve the issue of 'kind' not being recognized as a command on Windows after installation, you need to do the following:

1. Rename the downloaded executable file from `kind-windows-amd64.exe` to `kind.exe`.
2. Place this renamed file in a specific folder.
3. Add that folder to your system's PATH environment variable.

After completing these steps, you should be able to use the `kind` command in your command prompt.

answer_llm:
The TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask is likely due to a version mismatch between Flask and Werkzeug. In video 10.3, this error occurred when using Flask version 2.2.2 along with Werkzeug version 2.2.2. To resolve this issue, it is recommended to pin the version of Flask to an older version, specifically Flask==2.1.3, using the command:

```
pipenv install Flask==2.1.3
```

This should alleviate the TypeError.
answer_orig:
Problem Description:
In video 10.3, when I was testing a flask service, I got the above error. I ran docker run .. in one terminal. When in second terminal I run python gateway.py, I get the above error.
Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma
question: What solution can you offer for the TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask?

answer_llm:
The TypeError you encounter in video 10.3 while running `docker` and then `python gateway.py` is likely due to a version mismatch between Flask and Werkzeug. The specific error message you mentioned is `TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'unbound_message' while importing Flask`. This occurs when an older version of Werkzeug (2.2.2) is used with a newer version of Flask (2.2.2). 

To resolve this issue, you can downgrade Flask to an older version, such as Flask==2.1.3, by running the command `pipenv install Flask==2.1.3`. This should eliminate the TypeError and allow your script to run properly.

answer_llm:
When you encounter the error 'aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice' while using 'aws ecr get-login --no-include-email', you should instead use the following command:

```
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
```

Make sure to replace the fields in red with your specific region and AWS account ID. Alternatively, if you have a default region configured, you can run:

```
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
```
answer_orig:
As per AWS documentation:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html
You need to do: (change the fields in red)
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
Alternatively you can run the following command without changing anything given you have a default region configured
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
Added by Humberto Rodriguez

answer_llm:
The solution for the TensorFlow Serving error on an Apple M1 Mac is to use a different Docker image specifically for ARM architecture. You can do this by pulling the image with the following commands:

1. Pull the suitable image:
   ```
   docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
   ```

2. Run the Docker container using the pulled image:
   ```
   docker run -it --rm \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
   -e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
   emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
   ```

For more details, you can visit the GitHub page: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm.
answer_orig:
While trying to run the docker code on M1:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
It outputs the error:
Error:
Status: Downloaded newer image for tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
[libprotobuf FATAL external/com_google_protobuf/src/google/protobuf/generated_message_reflection.cc:2345] CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
what():  CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
qemu: uncaught target signal 6 (Aborted) - core dumped
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     8 Aborted                 tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution
docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
docker run -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
See more here: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm
Added by Daniel Egbo

question: Who provided the solution for the TensorFlow Serving issue on Apple M1 Mac?

answer_llm:
If you encounter an "Illegal instruction" error while running tensorflow/serving on a Mac M2 Apple Silicon, you should use the `bitnami/tensorflow-serving` base image instead. You can launch it using the following command:

```bash
docker run -d \
--name tf_serving \
-p 8500:8500 \
-p 8501:8501 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
-e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
```

Alternatively, you can use a `docker-compose.yaml` configuration:

```yaml
version: '3'
services:
  tf_serving:
    image: bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
    volumes:
      - ${PWD}/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1
    ports:
      - 8500:8500
      - 8501:8501
    environment:
      - TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model
```

Then run it with:

```bash
docker compose up
``` 

This should resolve the issue.

```bash
docker run -d \
```


This command runs the container in detached mode, maps the necessary ports, mounts your model directory, and sets the environment variable for the model name.

answer_llm:
If HPA doesn’t show CPU metrics and the CPU metrics show as unknown, you can follow these steps:

1. **Delete the HPA**:
   Run the command: `kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa`.

2. **Reapply the Metrics Server**:
   Execute the command to apply the metrics server configuration:
   ```
   kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
   ```

3. **Create the HPA** again to resolve the issue.

These steps should address the CPU metrics reporting problem.
answer_orig:
Problem: CPU metrics Shows Unknown
NAME         REFERENCE           TARGETS         MINPODS   MAXPODS   REPLICAS   AGE
credit-hpa   Deployment/credit   <unknown>/20%   1         3         1          18s
FailedGetResourceMetric       2m15s (x169 over 44m)  horizontal-pod-autoscaler  failed to get cpu utilization: unable to get metrics for resource cpu: unable to fetch metrics from resource metrics API:
Solution:
-> Delete HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
-> kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
-> Create HPA
This should solve the cpu metrics report issue.
Added by Priya V

question: What are the errors indicated for the FailedGetResourceMetric?

answer_llm:
To delete an HPA (Horizontal Pod Autoscaler) in Kubernetes, you can use the following command:

```
kubectl delete hpa <hpa-name>
```

Replace `<hpa-name>` with the name of your HPA. For example, to delete an HPA named `credit-hpa`, you would run:

```
kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa
```

answer_llm:
If you encounter errors with Istio during KServe installation, the issue may occur because Istio fails to update resources and you are using kubectl version greater than 1.25.0. To resolve this, follow these steps:

1. Check your kubectl version by running `kubectl version`.
2. Edit the "quick_install.bash" file by downloading it with curl without executing it, instead of running the bash command directly. 
3. Modify the versions of Istio and Knative as specified in the matrix on the KServe website.
4. After making the edits, run the bash script again.

This should help you successfully install KServe without encountering Istio-related errors.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
Running this:
curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kserve/kserve/release-0.9/hack/quick_install.sh" | bash
Fails with errors because of istio failing to update resources, and you are on kubectl > 1.25.0.
Check kubectl version with kubectl version
Solution description
Edit the file “quick_install.bash” by downloading it with curl without running bash. Edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website.
Run the bash script now.
Added by Andrew Katoch

answer_llm: A midterm project should ideally cover content up to module-06, according to your cohort's syllabus. It should include an interesting problem, a corresponding dataset, and an explanation of how a model can be utilized to address the problem. The project should involve preparing the data and conducting exploratory data analysis (EDA), analyzing important features, training multiple models, tuning their performance, and selecting the best model. Additionally, you should export your findings into a script, and deploy your model locally with Docker, with bonus points for cloud deployment. It is important to document anything not covered in class.
answer_orig:
Answer: Ideally midterms up to module-06, capstones include all modules in that cohort’s syllabus. But you can include anything extra that you want to feature. Just be sure to document anything not covered in class.
Also watch office hours from previous cohorts. Go to DTC youtube channel and click on Playlists and search for {course yyyy}. ML Zoomcamp was first launched in 2021.

question: Will there be a compiled list of links to submitted projects for peer review?

answer_llm:
Emails in the peer review process for projects are hashed using the SHA-1 algorithm. To compute the hash, you can use the following Python code:

```python
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
    return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
```

You need to enter your email address as a string and run the code to get your hashed email. The resulting hash value should be used to find your assigned projects for review in the provided spreadsheet.

answer_llm:
To find the projects you need to review for the capstone, follow these steps:

1. Use the provided link to access the list of all submitted projects for evaluation: [Capstone submission link](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdgoepohpgbM4MWTAHWuXa6r3NXKnxKcg4NDOm0bElAdXdnnA/viewform).
2. You will find 3 assigned peer projects that you need to review. To locate your specific projects, you need to derive the hash value of your email address.
3. Run the following Python code to compute your hash value:
   ```python
   from hashlib import sha1
   def compute_hash(email):
       return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
   # Example usage **** enter your email below (your_email@gmail.com)****
   email = "your_email@gmail.com"
   hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
   print("Original Email:", email)
   print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
   ```
4. Access the spreadsheet using this link: [Spreadsheet with hashed emails](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true).
5. Search for 3 identical entries corresponding to your hashed email value in the spreadsheet to find the peer projects assigned to you for review.

Make sure to complete your reviews within the evaluation deadline.

I am not sure how the project evaluate assignment works? Where do I find this? I have access to all the capstone 2 project, perhaps, I can randomly pick any to review.
Answer:
The link provided for example (2023/Capstone link ): https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdgoepohpgbM4MWTAHWuXa6r3NXKnxKcg4NDOm0bElAdXdnnA/viewform contains a list of all submitted projects to be evaluated. More specific, you are to review 3 assigned peer projects. In the spreadsheet are 3 hash values of your assigned peer projects. However, you need to derive the your hash value of your email address and find the value on the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading.
To calculate your hash value run the python code below:
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
# Example usage **** enter your email below (Example1@gmail.com)****
email = "Example1@gmail.com"
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
Edit the above code to replace Example1@gmail.com as your email address
Store and run the above python code from your terminal. See below as the Hashed Email (SHA-1) value
You then go to the link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true
Lastly, copy the “Hashed Email (SHA-1): bd9770be022dede87419068aa1acd7a2ab441675” value and search for 3 identical entries. There you should see your peer project to be reviewed.

answer_llm:
To calculate your email hash for project evaluation, follow these specific steps:

1. Use the provided Python code to compute your hash value. Here is the code you need to use:

   ```python
   from hashlib import sha1

   def compute_hash(email):
       return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()

   # Example usage
   email = "YOUR_EMAIL_HERE"  # Replace YOUR_EMAIL_HERE with your actual email address
   hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
   print("Original Email:", email)
   print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
   ```

2. Replace `YOUR_EMAIL_HERE` with your actual email address in the code.

5. In the spreadsheet, find the column labeled `(reviewer_hash)` and search for your hashed email value.

6. Copy the corresponding value and look for 3 identical entries. This will show you the peer projects assigned to you for review.

answer_llm: You must supply a train.py file because it will be used by your peers to review your midterm project and to ensure that your training process works on someone else’s system. Additionally, having a train.py file is important because running a Python script for training a model is much simpler than running a notebook, which aligns with how training jobs are typically handled in real life.
answer_orig:
Answer: The train.py file will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. It is for them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system. It should also be included in the environment in conda or with pipenv.

question: Why must I supply a train.py if I already have a notebook.ipynb?

question: How will my peers review my midterm project?

answer_llm: The purpose of the train.py file is to provide a Python script for training a model, which simplifies the training process compared to using a notebook. Additionally, the train.py file is necessary for peers to review your midterm project, as it enables them to cross-check that your training process works on their system. It should also be included in the environment setup using conda or pipenv.
answer_orig:
Answer: The train.py file will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. It is for them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system. It should also be included in the environment in conda or with pipenv.
Odimegwu David
question: What is the purpose of the train.py file?

answer_llm: You should include the `train.py` file in conda or pipenv because it will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. This file allows them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system. Additionally, running a Python script for training a model (like `train.py`) is much simpler than running a notebook (like `notebook.ipynb`), which reflects how training jobs are typically conducted in real life.
answer_orig:
Answer: The train.py file will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. It is for them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system. It should also be included in the environment in conda or with pipenv.
Odimegwu David
question: Why should I include train.py in conda or pipenv?

answer_llm: The training process can be verified on another system by ensuring that all necessary components for reproducibility are present. This includes having the dataset and instructions available, as well as checking for any obvious errors. Additionally, for specific training runs, reproducibility with TensorFlow can be achieved by following the instructions to set a random seed and enable operational determinism. This means that if the script is executed multiple times, consistent results should be obtained.
answer_orig:
Answer: The train.py file will be used by your peers to review your midterm project. It is for them to cross-check that your training process works on someone else’s system. It should also be included in the environment in conda or with pipenv.
Odimegwu David

answer_llm: To avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with your Docker container, you should put the custom column transformer class into a separate module. Then, import this module in both the script that saves the model (e.g., train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g., predict.py). This will ensure that the class can be found when the model is loaded by pickle, as it will no longer look for the class in the `__main__` module where it was originally saved.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: How can I avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with my Docker container?

answer_llm: Pickle throws an attribute error when running a Docker container with Waitress due to the custom column transformer class being referenced in the global namespace as `__main__.<custom_class>`. When the model was saved, it was saved from the `__main__` module (e.g., `python train.py`). However, when Waitress loads the `predict_app` module, it cannot find `__main__.<custom_class>`, leading to the error. This issue does not occur when using Flask directly, as the class definition would be in the same namespace when running `predict.py`. To resolve this, you should place the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model and the script that loads it.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: What causes pickle to throw an attribute error when running a Docker container with waitress?

answer_llm:
Pickle works with Flask but not with Waitress because of how the custom column transformer class is referenced in the module namespace. When the model was saved, it was done from the `__main__` module. This means that when you use Pickle, it looks for the class in the global namespace as `__main__.<custom_class>`. 

In the case of Flask, when you run `predict.py` directly, the class is in the same namespace that was used when the model was saved, thus it works. However, when using Waitress to serve the app, Waitress loads the `predict_app` module and attempts to call `pickle.load`, which can't find `__main__.<custom_class>`, resulting in an error. 

To resolve this, you should move the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model and the script that loads the model.

Common techniques to handle outliers in a dataset include:

1. Dataset transformation (e.g., log transformation)
2. Clipping high values
3. Dropping these observations
answer_orig:
There are different techniques, but the most common used are the next:
Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
Clipping high values
Dropping these observations
Alena Kniazeva
question: What are common techniques to handle outliers?

answer_llm: Yes, dataset transformation, such as log transformation, can help with outliers in a dataset. This is one of the common techniques used to handle outliers.

Clipping high values

question: Can dataset transformation help with outliers?

answer_llm: Clipping high values refers to a technique used to handle outliers in a dataset. It involves setting a maximum threshold such that any data point above this threshold is capped or "clipped" to the threshold value. This prevents extremely high values from disproportionately influencing statistical analyses and model performance.
answer_orig:
There are different techniques, but the most common used are the next:
Dataset transformation (for example, log transformation)
Clipping high values
Dropping these observations

answer_llm:
If Bento fails to import the module 'service' with a 'No module named sklearn' error, the issue is likely caused by an incorrect package name in the `bentofile.yaml` file. You should modify the packages list in `bentofile.yaml` to include `scikit-learn` instead of `sklearn`. Here’s how the updated packages list should look:

```yaml
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
``` 

This change should resolve the error.
answer_orig:
I was getting the below error message when I was trying to create docker image using bentoml
[bentoml-cli] `serve` failed: Failed loading Bento from directory /home/bentoml/bento: Failed to import module "service": No module named 'sklearn'
Solution description
The cause was because , in bentofile.yaml, I wrote sklearn instead of scikit-learn. Issue was fixed after I modified the packages list as below.
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
Asia Saeed

answer_llm: The cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML could be due to setting DictVectorizer or One-Hot Encoding (OHE) to sparse while training. When this is stored in a pipeline or custom object during the model saving stage in train.py, it leads to inconsistent input sizes when the custom object is called in service.py. This results in each input being converted to differently sized sparse matrices, causing a failure to batch them. To rectify this issue, it is recommended to set the `batchable` parameter to False in the BentoML model signatures during the saving of the model in train.py.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: What might be the cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML?

answer_llm: You may experience different sized sparse matrices in BentoML production when using DictVectorizer or OneHotEncoder (OHE) if you have set them to produce sparse matrices during training. Specifically, when you save the model in the `train.py` stage, this configuration can cause issues later in `service.py`, where each input might be converted to a differently sized sparse matrix. This inconsistency in length prevents batching, which is required for production. To resolve this, you should set the `batchable` option to `False` for your bentoml model signatures during the model saving stage.
answer_orig:

This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: Why do I get different sized sparse matrices in BentoML production when using DictVectorizer or OHE during training?

answer_llm: To avoid errors in production when using BentoML model signatures, you should set `batchable` to `False`. This is necessary if you are using a `DictVectorizer` or `OneHotEncoder` set to sparse during training, as this can lead to inconsistent input sizes and batching issues when the model is called in production.

If you receive an unauthorized message when pushing a Docker image to Google Container Registry, indicating that you don't have the needed permissions, you should first ensure that you have the Google Cloud SDK installed. You can install it by following the instructions here: https://cloud.google.com/sdk/docs/install. After installing the SDK, execute the following command in your console:

```bash
gcloud auth configure-docker
```
answer_orig:
When you try to push the docker image to Google Container Registry and get this message “unauthorized: You don't have the needed permissions to perform this operation, and you may have invalid credentials.”, type this below on console, but first install https://cloud.google.com/sdk/docs/install, this is to be able to use gcloud in console:
gcloud auth configure-docker
(Jesus Acuña)

answer_llm:
If you're unable to install `tflite_runtime` in a pipenv environment, it may be due to version compatibility issues, specifically with Python 3.10, as this version of TFLite does not run on it. To resolve this, you should install Python 3.9 instead, after which you should be able to install `tflite_runtime` without any issues. 

You can check all available versions of `tflite_runtime` at [this link](https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/). If you find that your setup does not match any available combinations, you can explore options at [this GitHub repository](https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite) and install a necessary version using pip, like so:

```
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
```

Alternatively, if none of these solutions work, consider using the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development, and use Docker for testing Lambda.
answer_orig:
I am getting this error message when I tried to install tflite in a pipenv environment
Error:  An error occurred while installing tflite_runtime!
Error text:
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for tflite_runtime
This version of tflite do not run on python 3.10, the way we can make it work is by install python 3.9, after that it would install the tflite_runtime without problem.
Pastor Soto
Check all available versions here:
https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
If you don’t find a combination matching your setup, try out the options at
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
which you can install as shown in the lecture, e.g.
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
Finally, if nothing works, use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development, and use Docker for testing Lambda.
Rileen Sinha (based on discussions on Slack)

answer_llm:
If the standard installation methods don't work, you can try installing Kind via the Go package. Here are the steps:

1. Download and Install Go from [here](https://go.dev/doc/install).
2. Confirm the installation by typing `go version` in the Command Prompt.
3. Install Kind by running the command: `go install sigs.k8s.io/kind@v0.20.0`.
4. Confirm the installation by checking the version with `kind --version`.

This method works effectively if you encounter challenges with the other installation methods.

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'ImageDataGenerator name scipy is not defined' error, follow these steps:

4. After installing, restart the Jupyter kernel and try again.

answer_llm:
If you encounter an UnidentifiedImageError while testing a model locally on a test-image data, the solution is to modify the image URL you are using. Specifically, add "?raw=true" after the image file extension in the URL. For example, you should change the URL from:

`url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'`

to:

`url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true'`
answer_orig:
In deploying model part, I wanted to test my model locally on a test-image data and I had this silly error after the following command:
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
X = preprocessor.from_url(url)
I got the error:
UnidentifiedImageError: cannot identify image file <_io.BytesIO object at 0x7f797010a590>
Solution:
Add ?raw=true after .jpg in url. E.g. as below
url = ‘https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true’
Bhaskar Sarma
question: What is the solution if I get an UnidentifiedImageError while testing a model locally on a test-image data?

answer_llm:
To fix the error 'cannot identify image file' when using an image URL in your model, you need to append `?raw=true` at the end of the image URL. For example, change the URL from:

```
https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg
```

to:

```
https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true
```

answer_llm:
To avoid the `UnidentifiedImageError` in your deployment, you should add `?raw=true` after the image file extension in your GitHub image URL. For example, change:

```
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
```

to:


question: What change should I make to a GitHub image URL to avoid UnidentifiedImageError in my deployment?

answer_llm:
You get the UnidentifiedImageError with a .jpg image from a GitHub URL during model testing because the URL you are using does not directly point to the raw image file. When using a GitHub URL, you need to append "?raw=true" to the end of the URL to properly access the image. For example, instead of using:

```python
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg'
```

you should use:

```python
url = 'https://github.com/bhasarma/kitchenware-classification-project/blob/main/test-image.jpg?raw=true'
```

This change allows the preprocessor to correctly identify and process the image file.
answer_orig:

2. **Adjust the dependencies** as necessary to resolve any mismatches or issues.
3. **Save the changes** you made to the Pipfile.
4. **Run the command** `pipenv lock` in your terminal to update the Pipfile.lock based on the changes made in the Pipfile. 

This process will help fix the dependency issues you may be encountering.

1. **AWS (Amazon Web Services)** - Offers microinstances for free for an extended period.
2. **GCP (Google Cloud Platform)** - Also provides microinstances for free for a prolonged duration.

These platforms can help you deploy your Docker images without incurring costs.

answer_llm:
To convert the `day_of_the_month` and `month_of_the_year` columns into a single `day_of_the_year` column in pandas, follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from integer to string:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column (which contains strings like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into corresponding month numbers (as strings):
   ```python
   df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map({'jan': '1', 'feb': '2', 'mar': '3', 'apr': '4', 'may': '5', 'jun': '6', 'jul': '7', 'aug': '8', 'sep': '9', 'oct': '10', 'nov': '11', 'dec': '12'})
   ```

3. Create a datetime object from the day and month:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(dict(year='2055', month=df['month'], day=df['day_of_the_month']))
   ```

4. Extract the day of the year from the datetime object:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

Now, the `day_of_year` column will contain the corresponding day of the year as integers.
answer_orig:
Problem description: I have one column day_of_the_month . It has values 1, 2, 20, 25 etc. and int . I have a second column month_of_the_year. It has values jan, feb, ..dec. and are string. I want to convert these two columns into one column day_of_the_year and I want them to be int. 2 and jan should give me 2, i.e. 2nd day of the year, 1 and feb should give me 32, i.e. 32 nd day of the year. What is the simplest pandas-way to do it?
Solution description:
convert dtype in day_of_the_month column from int to str with df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
convert month_of_the_year column in jan, feb ...,dec into 1,2, ..,12 string using map()
convert day and month into a datetime object with:
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
dict(
year='2055',
month=df['month'],
day=df['day']
)
)
get day of year with: df['day_of_year']=df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
(Bhaskar Sarma)
question: How can I convert day_of_the_month and month_of_the_year columns into a single day_of_the_year column in pandas?

answer_llm:
The simplest way to get the day of the year from day and month columns in pandas, according to Bhaskar Sarma, is to follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from int to str:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column from strings (e.g., jan, feb, ...) into month numbers (1, 2, ..., 12):
   ```python
   df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map({'jan': '1', 'feb': '2', ...})
   ```

3. Combine day and month into a datetime object:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',
           month=df['month'],
           day=df['day']
       )
   )
   ```

4. Obtain the day of the year:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ``` 

By following these steps, you can successfully calculate the day of the year from the day and month columns.

question: What is the simplest way to get the day of the year from day and month columns in pandas according to Bhaskar Sarma?

answer_llm:
To transform month_of_the_year values like 'jan' and 'feb' into integers in pandas, you can use the `map()` function to convert the string representations of the months into corresponding integers. Here's a step-by-step approach based on your context:

1. First, convert the `month_of_the_year` values (like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into integer strings (1 for 'jan', 2 for 'feb', ..., 12 for 'dec') using the `map()` method.

2. Then, you can create a new DataFrame column that represents the day of the year by converting both the day and the month into a datetime object using `pd.to_datetime()`.

Here is a condensed example of how you can achieve this:

```python
import pandas as pd

# Example DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'day_of_the_month': [1, 2, 2, 28],
    'month_of_the_year': ['jan', 'feb', 'mar', 'dec']
})

# Map month names to their respective integer values
month_map = {'jan': 1, 'feb': 2, 'mar': 3, 'apr': 4, 
             'may': 5, 'jun': 6, 'jul': 7, 'aug': 8, 
             'sep': 9, 'oct': 10, 'nov': 11, 'dec': 12}

df['month'] = df['month_of_the_year'].map(month_map)

# Convert day and month to datetime and get day of the year
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
    dict(year='2055', month=df['month'], day=df['day_of_the_month'])
)
df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear

# The result will give you the transformed values
print(df[['day_of_the_month', 'month_of_the_year', 'day_of_year']])
```

This code will provide you with the `day_of_year` for corresponding `day_of_the_month` and `month_of_the_year` values as integers.

To format day and month columns into a datetime object using pandas, follow these steps:

1. Convert the `day_of_the_month` column from integer to string:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```

2. Convert the `month_of_the_year` column (which contains month names like jan, feb, etc.) into corresponding numerical string values (1, 2, ..., 12) using `map()`.

3. Create a datetime object by combining the day and month:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',  # You can adjust the year as needed
           month=df['month'],
           day=df['day']
       )
   )
   ```

4. Get the day of the year from the newly created datetime object:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

question: What steps are needed to format day and month columns into a datetime object using pandas?

answer_llm:
To get the day of the year from a date formatted column using pandas, you can follow these steps:

1. Ensure you have two columns: one for the day of the month (as integers) and another for the month of the year (as strings).
2. Convert the day column from integers to strings using:
   ```python
   df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
   ```
3. Convert the month strings (like 'jan', 'feb', etc.) into corresponding month numbers (as strings) using `map()`.
4. Create a datetime object by combining the year, month, and day into a new column:
   ```python
   df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
       dict(
           year='2055',
           month=df['month_of_the_year'],
           day=df['day_of_the_month']
       )
   )
   ```
5. Finally, extract the day of the year using:
   ```python
   df['day_of_year'] = df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
   ```

This will give you a new column `day_of_year` with the corresponding day of the year for each date.
answer_orig:
Problem description: I have one column day_of_the_month . It has values 1, 2, 20, 25 etc. and int . I have a second column month_of_the_year. It has values jan, feb, ..dec. and are string. I want to convert these two columns into one column day_of_the_year and I want them to be int. 2 and jan should give me 2, i.e. 2nd day of the year, 1 and feb should give me 32, i.e. 32 nd day of the year. What is the simplest pandas-way to do it?
Solution description:
convert dtype in day_of_the_month column from int to str with df['day_of_the_month'] = df['day_of_the_month'].map(str)
convert month_of_the_year column in jan, feb ...,dec into 1,2, ..,12 string using map()
convert day and month into a datetime object with:
df['date_formatted'] = pd.to_datetime(
dict(
year='2055',
month=df['month'],
day=df['day']
)
)
get day of year with: df['day_of_year']=df['date_formatted'].dt.dayofyear
(Bhaskar Sarma)
question: How can I use pandas to get the day of the year from a date formatted column?

question: Can you provide a step-by-step guide to create a bar chart for predictions?

answer_llm:
To plot classes and their corresponding predictions after training a neural net, follow these steps:

1. Zip the classes and predictions into pairs using `dict(zip(classes, predictions)).items()`.
2. Unpack the zipped pairs into two separate variables: `classes` and `predictions`.
3. Create a figure for the plot with the desired size using `plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))`.
4. Use a bar graph to visualize the predictions for each class by calling `plt.bar(classes, predictions)`.

This will create a bar chart that displays the predictions for each class.

question: What are the necessary steps to plot classes and their corresponding predictions?

answer_llm:
To visualize the predictions per class after training a neural network using matplotlib, you can use the following steps:

1. First, create a list of your classes and corresponding predictions.
2. Use the `zip` function to pair them together.
3. Create a bar chart with matplotlib.

Here’s a sample code:

```python
classes, predictions = zip(*dict(zip(classes, predictions)).items())
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 3))
plt.bar(classes, predictions)
```

This will display a bar chart where the x-axis represents the classes, and the y-axis represents the predictions.

To install the CUDA toolkit and cuDNN for TensorFlow on Windows, follow these steps:

1. **Install Nvidia drivers**: Download and install the appropriate drivers from [Nvidia's website](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx).

2. **Install Anaconda**: Download and install Anaconda from [Anaconda's website](https://www.anaconda.com/).

3. **TensorFlow Installation Options**: Choose one of the following methods to install TensorFlow:
   - Install the package `tensorflow-gpu` in Anaconda.
   - Use the TensorFlow installation guide available [here](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#windows-native).

4. **Install CUDA Toolkit**: Download and install the CUDA toolkit version 11.x.x from the [CUDA Toolkit Archive](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive).

5. **Install cuDNN**: Download and install cuDNN from the [Nvidia cuDNN download page](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).

After completing these steps, you should be able to train and perform inference using TensorFlow with GPU support.

question: What are the steps to install the CUDA toolkit and cuDNN for TensorFlow on Windows?

answer_llm:
To install TensorFlow-GPU using Anaconda, follow these steps:

1. Install the Nvidia drivers from the official Nvidia website: [Nvidia Driver Download](https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx).
2. Install Anaconda if you haven't already: [Anaconda Installation](https://www.anaconda.com/).
3. You have two options to install TensorFlow-GPU:
   - Install the package `tensorflow-gpu` directly in Anaconda.
   - Alternatively, use the TensorFlow installation method outlined on their official site: [TensorFlow Installation](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1).
4. If you are on WSL/Linux, make sure to follow step 4 to set up CUDA by environment. You may need to run the following command to set environment variables:
   ```
   echo ‘export XLA_FLAGS=--xla_gpu_cuda_data_dir=$CONDA_PREFIX/lib/> $CONDA_PREFIX/etc/conda/activate.d/env_vars.sh
   ```
5. Install the CUDA toolkit (version 11.x.x) from the CUDA toolkit archive: [CUDA Toolkit Archive](https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive).
6. Install cuDNN from the Nvidia website: [cuDNN Download](https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download).

After completing these steps, you should be able to perform training and inference with GPU support in TensorFlow.

question: What is the method to install TensorFlow-GPU using Anaconda?

answer_llm:
To install TensorFlow on WSL/Linux using pip, you can follow these steps:

1. Ensure you have the necessary hardware to support CUDA if you are planning to use GPU acceleration.
2. You can install TensorFlow along with CUDA support using the following command: 
   ```bash
   pip install tensorflow
   ```
3. For utilizing CUDA, refer to the CUDA on WSL documentation provided by NVIDIA: [CUDA Toolkit Documentation (nvidia.com)](https://nvidia.com).
4. If you haven't set up CUDA yet, make sure to install CUDA and cuDNN as they are required for running TensorFlow with GPU support. Check resources or guides available for setting this up specifically for your Linux distribution.

By following these instructions, you should be able to install TensorFlow successfully on WSL/Linux.

answer_llm:
To find help for uploading datasets on Kaggle, you can refer to the following steps:

1. **Kaggle API Setup**: You need to have a Kaggle account. Go to the Kaggle website, click on your profile image, select Account, and scroll down to the API box to create a new API token. This will download a `kaggle.json` file.

2. **Upload the JSON file**: Upload the `kaggle.json` file to the `.kaggle` folder in your environment.

3. **Set Permissions**: Run the command `!chmod 600 /home/jovyan/.kaggle/kaggle.json` to set the correct permissions for the file.

4. **Download Dataset**: Use the command `!kaggle datasets download -d <dataset_identifier>` to download the desired dataset.

5. **Unzip the Files**: Create a folder using `!mkdir data` and unzip your downloaded files with `!unzip <filename>.zip -d data`.

These steps provide a streamlined process for uploading datasets from Kaggle.

answer_llm: The order is important in matrix multiplication because changing the order of the matrices can result in matrices of different sizes and usually different values. For instance, multiplying matrix A (with dimensions m x n) by matrix B (with dimensions n x p) yields a matrix C (of dimensions m x p). However, if the multiplication is reversed and you multiply B by A, you get a different matrix D (of dimensions n x n). Therefore, the order of multiplication affects both the size and the outcome of the result.
answer_orig:
When multiplying matrices, the order of multiplication is important.
For example:
A (m x n) * B (n x p) = C (m x p)
B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: Why is the order important in matrix multiplication?

answer_llm: When you change the order in matrix multiplication, the result is typically different. The multiplication of matrices is not commutative, meaning that A (m x n) * B (n x p) will produce a matrix C (m x p), whereas B (n x p) * A (m x n) will result in a different matrix D (n x n). C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values, highlighting the importance of the order in which matrices are multiplied.
answer_orig:

B (n x p) * A (m x n) = D (n x n)
C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.

question: What happens if I change the order in matrix multiplication?

answer_llm: The size of the resulting matrix changes with the order of multiplication. For example, if you multiply matrix A of size (m x n) by matrix B of size (n x p), the resulting matrix C will have the size (m x p). However, if you reverse the order and multiply matrix B (size (n x p)) by matrix A (size (m x n)), the resulting matrix D will have a different size of (n x n). Therefore, changing the order of multiplication results in matrices of different sizes and usually different values.

question: Can multiplying matrices in a different order produce the same result?

answer_llm:
An example that illustrates the impact of changing the order in matrix multiplication is as follows:

Consider two matrices A and B:
- Matrix A is of size (m x n)
- Matrix B is of size (n x p)

When you multiply them in the order A * B, the resulting matrix C will have a size of (m x p). 

However, if you change the order and multiply B * A, the resulting matrix D will have a different size of (n x n). 

Since C and D are matrices of different sizes, they usually contain different values as well. This demonstrates that the order of multiplication is crucial in matrix multiplication, and changing the order changes both the size and the result of the multiplication.

C and D are matrices of different sizes and usually have different values. Therefore the order is important in matrix multiplication and changing the order changes the result.
Baran Akın
question: Could you provide an example to illustrate the impact of changing the order in matrix multiplication?

question: Why must my GitHub repository be public for this course?

answer_llm:
To set up a Conda environment on your computer, you first need to install Anaconda or Miniconda if you haven't done so already. Once installed, you can create a new environment by running the command:

```
conda create -n ml-zoomcamp python=3.9
```

This command is run only the first time to create the environment. After the environment has been created, you can activate it using the command:

```
conda activate ml-zoomcamp
```

You will need to run this activation command each time you want to use the environment. Additionally, if you wish to reproduce your existing environment, you can export it using:

```
conda env export > environment.yml
```

And recreate it later with:

```
conda env create -f environment.yml
```

answer_llm: To resolve the error of Python 3.11 not being found when rerunning a Docker file in Windows, you should add the Python 3.11 installation folder to the PATH environment variable. After making this change, restart your system and then run the Docker file again. This should solve the error.
answer_orig:
When trying to rerun the docker file in Windows, as opposed to developing in WSL/Linux, I got the error of:
```
Warning: Python 3.11 was not found on your system…
Neither ‘pipenv’ nor ‘asdf’ could be found to install Python.
You can specify specific versions of Python with:
$ pipenv –python path\to\python
```
The solution was to add Python311 installation folder to the PATH and restart the system and run the docker file again. That solved the error.
(Added by Abhijit Chakraborty)

answer_llm: Deploying to DigitalOcean App Cloud costs about 5 USD/month. The container needs to remain active until the project's evaluation is complete.
answer_orig:
You may quickly deploy your project to DigitalOcean App Cloud. The process is relatively straightforward. The deployment costs about 5 USD/month. The container needs to be up until the end of the project evaluation.
Steps:
Register in DigitalOcean
Go to Apps -> Create App.
You will need to choose GitHub as a service provider.
Edit Source Directory (if your project is not in the repo root)
IMPORTANT: Go to settings -> App Spec and edit the Dockerfile path so it looks like ./project/Dockerfile path relative to your repo root
Remember to add model files if they are not built automatically during the container build process.
By Dmytro Durach

answer_llm: No, it is not necessarily best to train your model only on the most important features. While some features may offer more predictive value, any feature that can contribute additional predictive value should be included. It's advisable to predict with and without including certain features and to assess their impact on model performance. If excluding a feature results in a drop in performance, it should be retained; otherwise, it can be dropped.
answer_orig:
I’m just looking back at the lessons in week 3 (churn prediction project), and lesson 3.6 talks about Feature Importance for categorical values. At 8.12, the mutual info scores show that the some features are more important than others, but then in lesson 3.10 the Logistic Regression model is trained on all of the categorical variables (see 1:35). Once we have done feature importance, is it best to train your model only on the most important features?
Not necessarily - rather, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included (so, e.g. predict with & without including that feature; if excluding it drops performance, keep it, else drop it). A few individually important features might in fact be highly correlated with others, & dropping some might be fine. There are many feature selection algorithms, it might be interesting to read up on them (among the methods we've learned so far in this course, L1 regularization (Lasso) implicitly does feature selection by shrinking some weights all the way to zero).
By Rileen Sinha
question: Is it always best to train a model only on the most important features?

answer_llm: The example that covers Feature Importance for categorical values in lesson 3.6 refers to the churn prediction project. In this lesson, mutual information scores are discussed to show that some features are more important than others.
answer_orig:

Once we have done feature importance, is it best to train your model only on the most important features?
Not necessarily - rather, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included (so, e.g. predict with & without including that feature; if excluding it drops performance, keep it, else drop it). A few individually important features might in fact be highly correlated with others, & dropping some might be fine. There are many feature selection algorithms, it might be interesting to read up on them (among the methods we've learned so far in this course, L1 regularization (Lasso) implicitly does feature selection by shrinking some weights all the way to zero).
By Rileen Sinha
question: What example covers Feature Importance for categorical values in lesson 3.6?

answer_llm: Yes, features that contribute minimally to performance can be excluded, but it's not a strict rule. After conducting feature importance analysis, if a feature does not provide additional predictive value (i.e., excluding it does not drop performance), it can be dropped. However, it is also essential to consider correlations between features, as dropping some may be acceptable. Therefore, it is recommended to predict with and without including the feature to determine its actual impact on performance.

Not necessarily - rather, any feature that can offer additional predictive value should be included (so, e.g. predict with & without including that feature; if excluding it drops performance, keep it, else drop it). A few individually important features might in fact be highly correlated with others, & dropping some might be fine. There are many feature selection algorithms, it might be interesting to read up on them (among the methods we've learned so far in this course, L1 regularization (Lasso) implicitly does feature selection by shrinking some weights all the way to zero).
By Rileen Sinha
question: Should we exclude features that contribute minimally to performance?

answer_llm: The method that implicitly performs feature selection by shrinking some weights to zero is L1 regularization (Lasso).

question: What method implicitly performs feature selection by shrinking some weights to zero?

answer_llm: Yes, some important features can be highly correlated with others, and they can be dropped without affecting performance. It's noted that while certain features offer additional predictive value, if removing a highly correlated feature does not drop the model's performance, it may be acceptable to drop it.

It seems like you're looking for information on how to handle questions related to the course. Based on the context provided, here are the relevant points:

- If you miss a session, everything is recorded, so you won’t miss anything. You will have the opportunity to ask your questions in advance for office hours, and those will be covered during the live stream. Additionally, you can always ask questions in Slack.

If you have any more specific questions, feel free to ask!
answer_orig:
You can consider several different approaches:
Sampling: In the exploratory phase, you can use random samples of the data.
Chunking: When you do need all the data, you can read and process it in chunks that do fit in the memory.
Optimizing data types: Pandas’ automatic data type inference (when reading data in) might result in e.g. float64 precision being used to represent integers, which wastes space. You might achieve substantial memory reduction by optimizing the data types.
Using Dask, an open-source python project which parallelizes Numpy and Pandas.
(see, e.g. https://www.vantage-ai.com/en/blog/4-strategies-how-to-deal-with-large-datasets-in-pandas)
By Rileen Sinha

answer_llm: Technically, yes, you can complete the course using R or Scala. However, it is not advisable due to several reasons. Some homework assignments require specific Python library versions, and your answers may not align with multiple choice questions if you use languages other than Python 3.10, which is recommended for the 2023 cohort. Additionally, your peer-reviewers may not be familiar with R or Scala, which could result in penalties. You can create a separate repository for your own learning using other languages based on the course's lessons, but it is not advisable for submission purposes.

question: What is the necessary condition for TensorFlow and TensorFlow Serving versions to work together?

answer_llm:
If the TensorFlow Serving image isn't working properly, you can check the following:

1. Ensure that the TensorFlow and TensorFlow Serving versions match, as this could cause issues (as per the solution from the Slack channel).

2. If you encounter an "Illegal instruction" error on Mac M2 or M1, consider using the Bitnami TensorFlow Serving base image. You can run it using the following command:

   ```bash
   docker run -d \
   --name tf_serving \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -p 8501:8501 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
   -e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
   bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
   ```

3. In case you are facing issues with downloading the `tensorflow/serving` image on Apple M1, you can try pulling the `emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest` image and running it with:

   ```bash
   docker run -it --rm \
   -p 8500:8500 \
   -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
   -e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
   emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
   ```

Refer to the respective solutions based on your setup and errors encountered.
answer_orig:
The TF and TF Serving versions have to match (as per solution from the slack channel)
Added by Chiedu Elue
